column3: I like the simpler nature of this patch, but doesn't this mean that that the transaction trickling stuff for privacy turns itself off when the network is sufficiently busy?\n
Agree. If we want the trickling behaviour still, we should make it\nconditional on sufficient time having elapsed?\n
The trickle logic is essentially completely broken as it is.\nIt really should be fixed with a seperate patch.\n

Is there any substantial change in CPU load for a busy, listening, full
node?

On Sun, Apr 5, 2015, 6:08 PM Patrick Strateman notifications@github.com
wrote:

> with patch on both nodes:
> 2015-04-05 11:55:36 UpdateTip: new
> best=000000000000000082ccf8f1557c5d40b21edabb18d2d691cfbf87118bac7254
> height=300000 log2_work=78.499549 tx=38463789 date=2014-05-10 06:32:34
> progress=0.317754 c
I haven't measured that, but I cant see there being any substantial cpu overhead.\n

latency_fix both nodes: 3591 seconds\n2015-04-05 10:55:45 UpdateTip: new best=00000000839a8e6886ab5951d76f411475428afc90947ee320161bbf18eb6048  height=1  log2_work=33.000022  tx=2  date=2009-01-09 02:54:25 progress=0.000000  cache=1\n2015-04-05 11:55:36 UpdateTip: new best=000000000000000082ccf8f1557c5d40b21edabb18d2d691cfbf87118bac7254  height=300000  log2_work=78.499549  tx=38463789  date=2014-0
That is about a 28% speedup. Awesome.  Care to get started on a separate PR based on this which improves the trickle logic?\n

I've been playing with this a little bit and it looks pretty good.  I ran under a test harness that simulated 125 clients that sent 1-2 messages/sec each (ping/pongs) in order to take a look at changes in the load profile and it does roughly double the overhead, but on my system (2014 era decent consumer PC) I only see about 6% CPU utilization jumping to about 12% so it's probably negligible.  (Th
We can likely back off the timeout in the future, the current value is probably excessively conservative.\n
Wait, wait.  It looks like this pull is completely subsumed by #5989?  I suppose they need to go in together anyway...\n
ACK. Code looks good (really tiny nit: messageHandlerCondition could be declared static).\nRuns nicely on OSX, still uses ~no CPU when there is nothing to do.\n
Code changes look good to me, going to test this.\n
